reviewText: This movie has excellent animation combined with live action, wonderful actors and a great story line.  There was only a short section that didn't keep my attention - it is better for families with children from toddlers to pre-teens or older.The story is of a boy who is lackadaisical about doing his homework, working with his schoolmate team, getting up and to school on time, taking care of his personal grooming, etc.  He wishes he could have what he wants without having "to lift a finger."  Along comes a "magic gourd" to help fulfill his wishes.  The problem is, some of the things the boy wishes for (or the gourd perceives the boy wants), are taken from someone or somewhere else - not magically appearing.  The boy, Raymond ("Wang Bao" in the Chinese version), has a lot of adventures getting to fly and all of and being chased by a movie dinosaur that but he finds he spends more time trying to undo the things that the Magic Gourd ("Bailey" - US version, Hulu or Bao Hulu in the Chinese version) does.  Raymond does say he is sorry to those who he has wronged - especially at the end of the movie.  I do not feel this is a bad young man - he just has some lessons to learn - which he does.This movie was completed in 2007.  It is the first animated film that is a joint production of China and Disney: made by China Group Corporation and Hong Kong Centro Digital.  The US production is directed by Rick Dempsey who also did the English language adaptation. Per the featurette the movie took 4 years to get the script (the original book was written in the fifties), 2 years to film and edit. It took 140 animators 1 year to do the animation.The feature movie lasts 85 minutes and has a 30 minute featurette, Behind the Scenes of the Gourd (in Mandarin Chinese but with excellent subtitles), and the original theme song sung by "Baby Zhang" (Zhang Hanyun) in a very cute music video - also in Mandarin Chinese with Chinese characters subtitled.  The song and lyrics were adapted to English and sung by Megan Hilty for the US DVD release (1/27/09).  She also does the voice for Ms. Lee (Ms. Liu in the Chinese version).  There are also "bloopers" and a simple interactive game to play.The movie is available in English (with subtitles if wished), Mandarin and Cantonese language tracks.  When I watched the Behind the Scenes featurette, the Chinese directors, music director, actors, etc. talked about the various aspects of making the film.  It was nice to see and hear the actor who did the original voice for the Gourd, Cheng Peisi, who has also played protagonists (voice) for other Disney animated films.  If you watch the movie with the Mandarin Chinese soundtrack, you will hear the original Chinese actors' voices.The voices for the U.S production are Corbin Bleu - Magic Gourd, Megan Hilty as Ms. Lee, Takayo Fischer as Grandma, Drake Johnston as Raymond, etc.  The Chinese actors and voices are Gigi Lueng as Ms. Liu (Ms. Lee - Teacher), Zhu Qi Long as Wang Bao (Raymond in the US version),  Zheng Jia Hao, Wang Ji Kun, Lao Yi Jia and many others.  The movie was filmed in the city of Hangzhou, China.FYI:The DVD is available with a FAST PLAY feature where it plays all the way through for young children who just have to put the DVD into the player OR you can go to the Main Menu for the normal set up of language, subtitles, extra features, etc.  This is explained as soon as you press Menu on your DVD player once the DVD is read and starts playing.
summary: Chinese-US Disney Project Very Good Family Movie

reviewText: Woopak is reviewing a family flick?? No, it can`t be.....Well, every once in awhile, one needs a change of pace so please bear with me when I review this family-friendly flick. "The Secret of the Magic Gourd" is adapted from the Chinese original short story by Zhang Tian Yi and is now produced under the Disney flag. Just what is a gourd? A gourd is any of the several trailing or climbing plants related to the pumpkin, squash and cucumber and bearing fruits with a hard rind. This film offers nothing new, and is a cardboard cut-out of a family film; blending magical elements and a "coming of age" tale. Nope, it isn't going to win any awards, and I think it is meant to be this way--it is your usual run-of-the-mill kid flick with a very simple story so it can easily connect with kids. Adults may find it corny but kids may find it a little charming with a predictable message that may prove quite invaluable.Raymond is an inquisitive kid who likes doing things the easy way, he is lazy. He discovers a magical, mythical gourd while fishing one day after school. This magical talking gourd calls himself "Bailey" and it grant Raymond's every wish. Things seem to be looking up for young Raymond, but whenever Bailey tries to grant his wish, the results aren't to his liking most of the time--Raymond's world is turned upside down.Now, I have to admit, I am not a fan of kid flicks but I also have to acknowledge that these films do have their charm to parents and children. This film does everything straight-forward, and don't expect a film in the caliber of "Bridge to Terabithia" or "Zathura". "The Secret of the Magic Gourd" is a low budget affair, with the use of decent CGI, studio-quality set designs and a very simple story. Yes, it does very little to involve or connect with the adult mind and honestly, it may prove a little annoying at times. The film does have its charm, and kids will no doubt have no issues understanding what it is trying to say. It uses cheeky humor, sub-par special effects (the frog looks related to the gecko in the Geico insurance commercials) and to be frank, I wasn't impressed at all with the film's quality.However, the film does give a good opening for mothers to talk to their 8-10 year old kids to work hard, and that magic is not needed to achieve success at school--the greatest magical feeling can be had from the simplest things, and success through hard work is more fulfilling. Bailey has all the willingness to aid his youthful master, but it never works out to his liking most of the time. I supposed this is also a commentary with parents occasional disconnections with their kids, and that parents shouldn't always bail their kids out of their troubles. It is invaluable for growing kids to make mistakes, this is how they grow and mature.While I have to admit that I found some parts of the film amusing; Bailey's innocence, his attempts to grant Raymond's desires through his magic is so without responsibility, that usually results in ironically, humorous sequences. Toys coming alive seemed "borrowed" from Pixar's "Toy Story" and some parts of it does seem "cute" but borders dangerously close to becoming an annoyance. The film's problems arise when it doesn't make any valid attempts to connect the viewer to its story, the relationship between Raymond and Bailey is given very little opportunity is breathe. There is enormous potential for a "genie" and a lazy boy premise with the easy fix and hard work twist; but the film felt too rushed to realize its promise. The lead actor performed competently enough, but he had very little to work with.The secret to making a great family film is to keep young minds amazed and busy; while the adults keep interest and doesn`t mind the "cuteness". Even myths and magic have to have a set of rules to keep the story grounded and this film doesn't make any such attempts in presenting an intriguing complication. Its strong bits of "not needing magic and true magic is achieved from hard work" may have charm but it didn't establish a heart and soul in its proceedings.Ultimately, "The Secret of the Magic Gourd" isn't so bad as long as one remembers what he is watching; but it pales in comparison with Disney's or Pixar's other offerings. It carries some energy and very little momentum, the film isn't anything special and definitely isn't that creative. Kids will find "Bailey the Gourd" mildly interesting, (they love "Barney") but the entire family is better off watching something else for "movie night".RENTAL [2  Stars = mediocre]Video/Audio: 2.35 ratio anamorphic widescreen.
